description: The 'draw_graphing_function' is an educational tool that generates visualizations of mathematical functions, specifically rational functions and hyperbolas. It provides a clear, interactive way for students to understand the behavior of these functions, including asymptotic behavior and the shape of hyperbolas.

educational_standards.description: Identify whether or not a mathematical relation is a function.
Evaluate values for variables for a given function.
Identify whether or not a function is linear.

stimulus_type_specification.title: Available Images: Graphs of Rational Functions and Hyperbolas
stimulus_type_specification.description: The 'draw_graphing_function' can generate two types of visualizations: graphs of rational functions and hyperbolas. It accepts a 'GraphingFunction' object as input, which should contain the parameters of the function to be graphed. The function is designed to handle rational functions and hyperbolas specifically, and will not correctly graph other types of functions. The function also includes educational enhancements such as dashed lines to indicate asymptotes. This tool can be used in a variety of educational settings, from classroom instruction to self-study and homework help resources.

details: The function accepts a single input: a 'GraphingFunction' object
The 'GraphingFunction' object should contain the parameters of the function to be graphed
For rational functions, the 'GraphingFunction' object should contain 'a' and 'b' parameters
For hyperbolas, the 'GraphingFunction' object should contain 'x_radius' and 'y_radius' parameters
The function is designed to handle rational functions and hyperbolas specifically
The 'GraphingFunction' object must contain the correct parameters for the type of function to be graphed
The function will not correctly graph other types of functions
The function generates a graph of the input function
For rational functions, the graph includes dashed lines to indicate asymptotes
For hyperbolas, the graph includes separate branches for the positive and negative parts of the function
The graph is color-coded for clarity
